<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_device_open:
```c
int metal_device_open(const char *bus_name, const char *dev_name,
		      struct metal_device **device)
{
	struct metal_bus *bus;
	int error;

	if (!bus_name || !strlen(bus_name) ||
	    !dev_name || !strlen(dev_name) ||
	    !device)
		return -EINVAL;

	error = metal_bus_find(bus_name, &bus);
	if (error)
		return error;

	if (!bus->ops.dev_open)
		return -ENODEV;

	error = (*bus->ops.dev_open)(bus, dev_name, device);
	if (error)
		return error;

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
!strlen(dev_name)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Calling strlen(dev_name) can read past the object bounds if dev_name points to a non‑terminated character array. Although the conditional contains a prior !dev_name test (so a NULL pointer will not be passed to strlen thanks to left‑to‑right short‑circuit evaluation), there is no guarantee that dev_name refers to a null‑terminated array. Example violating scenario: caller passes a pointer to a buffer of length N that contains no '\0' within those N bytes; strlen(dev_name) will scan beyond the buffer until it finds a '\0', resulting in out‑of‑bounds access.
